qas.question: What plan was implemented in September 1941?
Which portion of the population underwent ghettoisation?
What occured on the 15th of December 1941?
How many Jews approximately lived in Hanover in 1938?
How many concentration camps were constructed in Hanover?
What act ended the ghettos in 1941?
After what conference were the Jews deported to Riga
What portion of the population was moved to better housing?
How many concentration camps were constructed in Hanover before the war?
When did the Russian army arrive to occupy Hanover?

context: In September 1941, through the "<a0_0><b5_0>Action Lauterbacher<b5_0/><a0_0/>" plan, a ghettoisation of the remaining <a1_0><b7_0>Hanoverian Jewish families<b7_0/><a1_0/> began. Even before <b6_0>the <a2_0>Wannsee Conference<b6_0/><a2_0/>, on 15 December 1941, the first Jews from Hanover were deported to Riga. A total of 2,400 people were deported, and very few survived. During the war <a4_0><b8_0>seven<b8_0/><a4_0/> concentration camps were constructed in Hanover, in which many Jews were confined. Of the approximately <a3_0>4,800<a3_0/> Jews who had lived in Hannover in 1938, fewer than 100 were still in the city when troops of the United States Army arrived on <b9_0>10 April 1945<b9_0/> to occupy Hanover at the end of the war.[citation needed] Today, a memorial at the Opera Square is a reminder of the persecution of the Jews in Hanover. After the war a large group of Orthodox Jewish survivors of the nearby Bergen-Belsen concentration camp settled in Hanover.
